data.title: Office Jobs Are for Losers: My Life as a Digital Nomad
data.meta_description: I remember sitting in my cubicle, the sound of keyboards clicking like a symphony of monotony. The fluorescent lights above buzzed annoyingly, casting a sickly yellow hue over everything. My life had…
data.text:
I remember sitting in my cubicle, the sound of keyboards clicking like a symphony of monotony. The fluorescent lights above buzzed annoyingly, casting a sickly yellow hue over everything. My life had become a routine of clocking in, clocking out, and existing in between. It felt like a bad episode of “The Office,” minus the charmingly awkward Dwight Schrute. One day, as I sat staring blankly at my screen, I had a sudden epiphany: Office jobs are for losers.

Now, before you get all riled up, hear me out. I don’t mean that everyone who works in an office is a loser. No, I’m talking about the lifestyle — being shackled to a desk, trading hours of your life for dollars, all while your soul slowly withers away. I decided I wasn’t going to be a part of it anymore.

The Great Escape

Quitting my job wasn’t exactly a spur-of-the-moment decision. It was more like a slow simmer, a build-up of tiny grievances that eventually boiled over. There was the time my boss scolded me for taking an extra two minutes on my lunch break. Or the endless meetings that could have been emails. Or the sheer absurdity of having to ask permission to go on vacation — like, why did I need someone’s approval to enjoy my…
